I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Development of the Northern Chu and Southern Ma 
Rivers Irrigation System Project.1  
 
2. 
The project is part of the government’s overall investment program for the Northern Chu 
and  Southern  Ma  Rivers  Irrigation  System  (NCSMRIS),  which  will  increase  water  productivity, 
reduce rural energy use, and improve food security.2 The NCSMRIS command area is located 
in  Thanh  Hoa  province  in  north  central  Viet  Nam  (see  Map).  Currently,  irrigators  within  the 
command  area  draw  water  from  the  Chu  and  Ma  rivers  through  one  large  and  many  small 
irrigation pumping stations. The completion of the Cua Dat multipurpose reservoir provides the 
opportunity to  convert  the  NCSMRIS from  an  energy-dependent  pumped  scheme  to  a  surface 
gravity  scheme,  reducing  energy  requirements  and  improving  the  reliability  of  irrigation 
deliveries from the Cua Dat reservoir. The overall government investment program will develop 
new  main  and  distribution  canals  and  rehabilitate  existing  irrigation  and  drainage  facilities, 
improve institutional capacity for water management, and enhance operation and maintenance 
(O&M) for NCSMRIS. It will contribute to efforts to adapt to climate change by increasing food 
production in an area less exposed than the main river deltas to the potential impact of sea level 
rise and projected yield reductions due to increased frequency of flood and drought events. This

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

A. 
 
3. 
Viet  Nam’s  transformation  from  a  net  importer  of  rice  to  one  of  the  world’s  largest 
exporters  began  in  1991.  However,  population  growth  (currently  about  1.4%  per  year)  and 
improvements  in  living  standards  are  causing  national  rice  consumption  to  increase  by  about 
2% per year. At current rice production levels, the present rice surplus of 4 million–5 million tons 
per  year—which  is  now  exported—will  be  absorbed  by  domestic  consumption  in  just  10–12 
years.  The  consequences  for  regional  food  security  will  be  considerable  unless  there  is  a 
corresponding  increase  in  production.  The  proportion  of  the  national  gross  domestic  product 
contributed by agriculture is declining, but economic growth requires continued increases in the 
production of food, fiber, and raw materials for other sectors.  
 
Paddy is the dominant food crop, accounting for 82% of the irrigated area in Viet Nam in 
4. 
2009. However, the area of land under paddy cultivation has decreased in recent years due to 
urban  expansion,  diversification  into  aquaculture  and  other  crops,  and  economic  growth  in 
nonagriculture  sectors,  with  increasing  demands  on  available  water  resources.  While  the  net 
available  land  for  agriculture  (especially  paddy)  is  limited  and  currently  declining,  the 
government  wishes  to  enhance  the  productivity  of  existing  land  and  food  security  through 
improvements to irrigation and drainage. The government consequently places a high priority on 
irrigation  modernization,  dam  safety,  and improved  water  resources  management. The  project 
will address these issues at the local level, and will contribute to ADB’s broader policy dialogue 
initiatives in the water and food sectors (paras. 6 and 8).

One  of 

 
the  major  objectives  of  the  government’s  draft  5-year  Socioeconomic 
5. 
Development  Plan  (SEDP,  2011–2015)  is  to  accelerate  agricultural  and  rural  industrialization 
and  modernization  to  (i)  facilitate  large-scale  agricultural  commodity  production  relevant  to 
market  demand  and  the  ecological  conditions  of  individual  regions;  and  (ii) increase  food 
security.  The  modernization  of  irrigation  and  drainage  systems  will  result  in  more  reliable, 
efficient,  and  equitable  water  services,  which  are  indispensable  foundations  for  agricultural 
modernization. In its National Water Resources Strategy, the government has defined the main 
objectives  for  the  water  sector  during  2006–2020  as  the  protection,  efficient  exploitation,  and 
sustainable  development  of  water  resources  on  the  basis  of  integrated  and  unified  water 
resources  management,  with  the  continuous  development  and  improvement  of  institutions, 
operations, and human resource capacity as priorities. 4 
 
The  Viet  Nam  Water  Sector  Review,  2009 5  lists  many  issues  facing  irrigation  (and 
6. 
particularly  the  NCSMRIS),  including  the  need  to  (i)  balance  tradeoffs  between  the  economic 
efficiency  of  improving  existing  infrastructure  versus  expansion  of  new  irrigated  areas; 
(ii) rehabilitate  existing  infrastructure,  much  of  which  is  30–40  years  old  and  suffers  from 
inadequate  expenditure on O&M;  (iii)  achieve  sustainable financing for O&M  and  rehabilitation 
of  irrigation  facilities,  given  that  central  and  provincial  government  budgets  are  insufficient  for 
major  refurbishment  and  the  current  government  subsidy  for  irrigation  service  fees  limits  the 
ability  of  irrigation  management  companies  (IMCs)  to  fully  cover  O&M;6 (iv)  improve  irrigation 
service  coverage,  with  an  average  of  only  about  68%  of  irrigation  design  areas  currently 
serviced;  (v) manage  water  quality  and  reduce  nonpoint  source  pollution  from  fertilizers  and 
pesticides,  which  pose  a  public  health  risk  in  many  areas;  and  (vi)  effectively  manage 
multipurpose reservoirs for irrigation, hydropower, and water supply.7  
 
7. 
Lessons  learned  from  recent  ADB  and  other  development  partners’  projects  in  the 
irrigation  subsector  indicate  that  a  comprehensive  approach  is  needed  to  achieve  full 
investment  potential,  including  interventions  to  (i)  build  the  capacity  of  key  agencies  and 
introducing  participatory  irrigation  management;  (ii)  eliminate  physical  impediments  to  efficient 
system  operation;  and  (iii)  provide  support  for  project  management.  Although  the  irrigation 
service fee subsidy aims to provide for IMC operations, additional resources must be raised by 
water user associations to operate and maintain lower order canals and on-farm facilities. ADB 
is monitoring the effectiveness of the O&M policy under ongoing sector activities. 
 
8. 
The SEDP sets out Viet Nam’s goal of becoming an industrialized nation by 2020, with a 
focus  on  poverty  alleviation  and  food  security.  Good  progress  has  been  made  in  reducing 
poverty  (which  fell  from  28.9%  in  2002  to  12.1%  in  2008),  but  the  northern  midland  and 
mountainous  region  (including  Thanh  Hoa  province)  remains  the  poorest  in  Viet  Nam,  with  a 
poverty level of 25.1% (2009). In Thanh Hoa province, 17.6% of the population lives below the 
poverty line. The SEDP envisages that by 2020, agriculture, forestry, and fisheries will account 
for around 19% of gross domestic product, and 41% of total national employment. The Ministry 
of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) 5-year plan for agriculture development  (2011–
2015) envisages a modernized and sustainable agriculture sector with a market orientation.

ADB’s country program and the project are aligned with these poverty and food security 
initiatives.  The  project  is  included  in  ADB’s  Viet  Nam  country  strategy  and  program.8   ADB’s 
assessment,  strategy,  and  road  map  for  the  agriculture,  natural  resources  and  environment 
sector  promotes  (i) 
improved  rural  productivity  and  (ii)  sustainable  natural  resources 
management  and  climate  change  resilience,  especially  for  land  and  water.  ADB  plays  a  lead 
role  among  development  partners  in  supporting  sustainable  water  resources  management 
through  financing  physical  infrastructure,  strengthening  government  capacity  and  coordinating 
institutional development initiatives for legislative and policy development. 9  
 
The existing irrigated area within the NCSMRIS command area is about 15,700 hectares 
10. 
(ha),  which  is  currently  served  by  about  160  pumped  irrigation  and  redistribution  schemes, 
drawing water from the Chu and Ma rivers and smaller tributaries. The government’s investment 
program will expand the irrigation area to a total command area of about 31,084 ha through the 
provision of gravity irrigation water from the Cua Dat reservoir, rehabilitation of existing facilities, 
and  development  of  new  facilities.  The  government’s  total  investment  program  is  divided  into 
three phases:10

control  structures  (financed  through  the  issuance  of  government  bonds).  The

from Doc Cay Dam to the junction of the north and south main canals (see Map). 
Phase 1 is currently under construction, with completion expected by mid-2015. 
Phase 2 (the proposed project to be financed by ADB and the government). 
Construction  of  the  new  north  (34.5  km)  and  south  (23.5  km)  main  canals  and 
development  of  lower-order  canals  and  on-farm  facilities,  planned  for  physical 
completion by mid-2017. 11 
Phase 3 (financing to be identified). Construction of the extension of the north 
main  canal  (km  34.5–km  47.3)  and  south  main  canal  (km  23.5–km  46.5),  and 
rehabilitation  of  the  existing  Southern  Ma  pumped  irrigation  scheme  command 
area.  The  government  intends  to  finance  phase  3  from  internal  or  external 
resources  starting  in  about  2014.  ADB’s  investment  is  not  contingent  on  the 
implementation of phase 3. 
 

Impact and Outcome 

B. 
 
11. 
The  impact  will  be  improved  water  and  land  productivity  of  irrigated  cropping  systems 
within the NCSMRIS command area, situated in Thanh Hoa province. The outcome will be the 
delivery of effective and timely irrigation services within NCSMRIS.

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

A. 
 
20. 
The project was prepared in two phases from March 2010 to August 2011. Phase A of 
the project preparatory TA (footnote 2) confirmed the overall hydrologic feasibility of NCSMRISP 
based on an irrigated command area of 31,084 ha, with an allowance for additional future water 
demands.  Hydrological  assessment  of  the  Cua  Dat  reservoir  indicated  that  the  operating  plan 
provides  adequate  water  for  irrigation  requirements  in  addition  to  other  demands,  and  the 
engineering  design  provides  adequate  capacity  to  cope  with  future  design  flows.  Construction 
costs  were  considered  realistic  based  on  norms  for  Viet  Nam.  The  phase  A  feasibility  study 
reviewed the relatively high development cost of $7,200 per ha and considered various design 
options  to  reduce  the  costs  and  resettlement  requirements,  but  no  significant  opportunities  for 
cost  savings  were  found.  No  serious  environmental  issues  were  identified.  Provisions  for  land 
acquisition, resettlement, and ethnic minorities were reviewed in relation to the guidelines of Viet 
Nam and ADB. Overall, the NCSMRIS was assessed as technically and economically feasible. 
 
Phase  B  of  the  project  preparatory  TA  prepared  the  investment  project  and  included 
21. 
studies  of  the  project  context  and  rationale,  description,  resources  and  outputs;  investment, 
funding  structure  and  financing;  implementation  and  operational  management;  and  project 
outcomes  and  impacts.  Detailed  annexes  were  prepared  on  financial  and  economic  analysis, 
project  administration,  poverty  reduction  and  social  issues,  gender,  resettlement,  ethnic 
minorities,  environment,  benefit  monitoring  and  evaluation,  and  preparation  of  terms  of 
reference  for  consulting  studies.  In-depth  studies  were  conducted  to  review  the  engineering 
designs,  resettlement,  agricultural  potential,  institutional  setting,  financial  management  and 
procurement capacity, which provided the basis of the investment proposal.  
 
B. 
 
The  main  benefits  will  be  to  agricultural  production  in  the  command  area,  and most  of 
22. 
the benefits will accrue as increases in crop production arising from the conversion of rainfed to 
irrigated  areas,  or  from  improvements  in  output  in  existing  irrigated  areas  resulting  from 
improved, more reliable water supply. The economic internal rate of return for the project (phase 
2)  is  estimated  at  22.4%. 16 At  a  12%  discount  rate,  the  net  present  value  is  $90.8 million 
(D1,902 billion). These results are robust across a range of sensitivity tests relating to changes 
in  project  cost  and  benefit  assumptions.  The  project  is  expected  to  lead  to  a  48%  increase  in 
average  household  incomes  (from  $567  to  $838  per  annum)  in  lowland  districts  (i.e., the 
districts of Tho Xuan, Yen Dinh, and Thieu Hoa) and a 100% increase (from $360 to $722 per 
annum) for  households  in upland  districts (i.e.,  Ngoc  Lac, Thuong Xuan, and Cam Thuy). The 
increase  in  average  upland  farm  income  will  be  greater  because  the  proportion  of  cultivated 
land that is rainfed (not irrigated) on upland farms is greater than that on lowland farms.

24. 
Beneficiaries. The  project covers 41 communes in six districts of Thanh Hoa province, 
in  which  78%–94%  of  the  population  is  involved  in  agricultural  production.  The  project  is 
expected  to  benefit  approximately  119,495  households  (466,000  people)  through  improved 
irrigation facilities and water supplies. The total cultivated area served by project is 23,899 ha, 
with  an  average  of  0.2  ha  of  cultivated  land  per  household.  Of  this,  15,758  ha  (66%)  is  fully 
irrigated and 8,141 ha (34%) rainfed or partially irrigated. With the project, 100% of the project 
area will be fully irrigated and all households will benefit.  
 
25. 
Poverty.  The  SEDP  sets  out  Viet  Nam’s  goal  of  becoming  an  industrialized  nation  by 
2020,  highlighting  the  need for  an  increased focus on  agricultural  production,  water  resources 
management,  food  security  and  poverty  reduction.  It  highlights  poverty  alleviation  as  an 
underlying  condition  for  achieving  these  goals,  projecting  the  percentage  of  the  population 
dependent on agriculture to decline from 85% to 50%. Poverty levels within the NCSMRIS area 
range from a low of 11.7% to 45.9% in remote communities, with 41,427 poor households within 
the  six  districts  covered  by  the  project.  Poverty  differs  significantly  between  urban  and  rural 
areas and between lowland rural areas and the hillier, upland districts. In lowland districts 13.9% 
of the population lives below the poverty line, and in upland districts 33.3%. In the project area, 
18.6%  of  households  are  poor  (weighted  average  based  on  the  relative  proportions  of  the 
project area in lowland and upland districts).

women  in  the  project,  and  ensure  they  derive  equal  benefits.  It  includes  specific  actions  to 
promote  the  participation  of  women  in  project  management,  training,  decision-making 
processes,  construction,  and  representation  in  WUAs  and  WUGs.  Specific  gender-related 
targets  include  (i)  women  shall  make  up  at  least  40%  of  WUG  and  WUA  representatives, 
trainees  in  project  technical  training  courses,  and  participants  in  non-agricultural,  occupational 
training;  (ii)  at  least  30%  of  CPO  and  PPMU  staff  shall  be  women;  and  (iii) gender-sensitive 
training shall  be  conducted for  all  staff. The results  of the GAP  will  monitored and reported  to 
ADB quarterly until project completion, based on sex-disaggregated data. The estimated cost of 
the GAP  is  included  in  the  project financing. The GAP  is  in  line  with  the government’s gender 
equality law and ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998).19

Resettlement.  The  project  has  been  classified  as  category  A  with  respect  to 
resettlement.  The  government  has  prepared  (i)  a  resettlement  framework  for  the  entire 
NCSMRIS  investment,  (ii)  a  resettlement  plan  for  the  government-financed  main  canal,  and              
(iii)  a  resettlement  plan  for  the  north  and  south  main  canal  construction,  which  have  been 
approved  by  government,  endorsed  by  ADB  and  posted  on  the  ADB  website.  Loan-financed 
consultants will prepare resettlement plans for the remaining works (such as lower-order canals) 
in  accordance  with  the  resettlement  framework  upon  completion  of  detailed  designs.  ADB  will 
finance  resettlement  allowances  for  the  project, and the government  has  agreed to finance all 
remaining  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  costs.  District-level  resettlement  units  have  been 
established by the provincial people’s committee to undertake resettlement work, as described 
in the resettlement framework. The project will engage an independent resettlement monitor. A 
due diligence study of resettlement activities on the main canal (initiated in December 2010) has 
been prepared and the government has agreed with the corrective action plan.21 
 
29. 
Under the NCSMRIS investment program, a total of approximately 5,218 households will 
be  affected  as  a  result  of  land  acquisition  or  resettlement  associated  with  construction  of  the 
main,  north  main,  south  main,  and  lower-order  canals,  based  on  social  surveys  and  initial 
engineering  designs.  Of  these,  1,343  households  are  considered  vulnerable  (about  381  are 
headed by women), and 3,043 households are considered severely affected, losing more than 
10% of their total landholding, and 439 are ethnic minority households.22 
 
30.  Within  the  project  area  (phase  2  of  the  NCSMRIS  investment  program),  approximately 
3,856  households  will  be  affected,  including  945  vulnerable  and  2,426  severely  affected 
households. 
 
31. 
Indigenous  peoples.  The  project  has  been  classified  as  category  A  with  respect  to 
indigenous  peoples.  The  project  directly  and  indirectly  affects  the  customary  rights  of  use, 
access  to  land  and  natural  resources,  and  livelihood  systems  of  ethnic  people  in  project 
communes.  Of the  119,495  households  benefited  by  the project,  11,448  households  comprise 
Thai  and  Muong  ethnic  minorities.  There  is  broad  ethnic  minority  community  support  for  the 
project, as documented in meetings with communities during project preparation. An indigenous 
peoples plan (locally termed an ethnic peoples’ development plan) has been prepared covering 
the entire NCSMRIS investment program to address ethnic minority impacts of the investment.23 
 
32. 
Environment.  The  project  has  been  classified  as  category  B  with  respect  to  the 
environment.  The  government  has  prepared  an  environmental  impact  assessment  for  the 
NCSMRIS investment program in accordance with its national guidelines,24 which was approved 
by MARD in June 2010. An initial environmental examination has been prepared in accordance 
with  ADB’s  guidelines,  based  on  the  environmental  impact  assessment. 25  Principal  issues 
identified  in  the  initial  environmental  examination  were  the  scale  of  land  acquisition  and 
displacement  of  affected  households  for  main  canal  infrastructure,  and  the  need  to  relocate 
about 157 graves. Inter-commune and district roads will be severed, requiring new bridges, and 
some 46 ha of forest land will cleared and an equivalent area of forest will be established within 
the vicinity. During construction, air and water pollution, soil erosion, and traffic congestion will
